origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Department of Mechanical Engineering.

did.unittitle: Department of Mechanical Engineering (University of Michigan) records 1914-2007, 1922-1941, 1993-2001
did.abstract: The University of Michigan Department of Mechanical Engineering dates from 1868, and it existed under various designations resulting from shifts and mergers in engineering, including at one time industrial engineering and applied mechanics. Records include minutes of faculty meetings, 1922-1941, and 1984-2007; advisory committee minutes, 1997-2007; and material on the 125th anniversary in 1993. Extensive visual materials document departmental activities and research including color and black and white photographs, contact sheets, slides, and negatives. The departmental website, as of June 2001, also forms a part of this record group.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This record group was received in several small accessions beginning in 1995, one large accession in 2001, and two additional small accessions in 2007 and 2009 (Donor no. 8391).

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: Department of Mechanical Engineering records are open with the exception of some personnel files closed in accord with university policy and state law.

The Department of Mechanical Engineering record group includes restricted material in the following categories:
Personnel Related Records -- Boxes 4 and 19

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Department of Mechanical Engineering (University of Michigan) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Department of Mechanical Engineering began in 1868 as the Mechanical Engineering program, with a mandate to instruct students in the new field of machine, power and marine engineering. Both the departments and its facilities grew steadily from 1900 to 1940. Although the department split and merged with other engineering departments over the years as new fields of engineering developed, one of the most significant shifts occurred in 1956 when the status of the Industrial Engineering section was elevated, and the department was renamed Industrial and Mechanical Engineering. Two years later Industrial Engineering split off from Mechanical Engineering altogether. Another major shift occurred in 1978 when the department merged with Applied Mechanics and became Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics (MEAM). However, in 2000 the departments split again, giving the department its present name. In 1984 the department left its home of eighty years on Central Campus (in the East and West Engineering Buildings) and moved to new, modern facilities, including laboratories, offices, and classrooms, on North Campus.

A detailed history of the department through 1993, including research projects and curricula, can be found in the publication 125 Years of Mechanical Engineering at The University of Michigan in the MEAM Publications record group (University of Michigan. Department of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics. Publications).

scopecontent.p: The Department of Mechanical Engineering record group is comprised of manuscript and visual materials transferred between 1995 and 2001. The materials are arranged in eight series Minutes, E-Mail to Faculty, Office Files, Contact Sheets, Photographs, Panoramic Prints and Slides, Negatives, and Website. The manuscript material covers the periods 1922 to 1941 and 1993 to 2007 while the visual materials are mainly from the time period 1985-2000. The earlier accessions include a series of faculty minutes covering the period from 1922 to 1941 and 1993 to 1999. The earlier accessions also include a small group of electronic mail correspondence (printout) that was sent from the central departmental office to the departmental faculty from 1993 to 1996. Subsequent accessions include a small selection of office files alphabetically arranged and additional faculty minutes.

Visual materials, documenting departmental activities ca. 1985-2000, form the bulk of the record group. The departmental website, as of June 2001, also forms a part of this record group. The visual materials in the record group include color and black and white photographs, contact sheets, slides, and negatives. The visual materials are either arranged by a numerical sequence or alphabetically by topic or last name. Materials in the numerical sequence filing system include 4 x 6 prints, contact sheets, and negatives. While the materials in the numerical sequence are categorized by format, the materials in this sequence were designed to form one system. That is the 4 x 6 prints, contact sheets, and negatives reference each other.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Dept. of Mechanical Engineering & Applied Mechanics.
controlaccess.subject: Mechanical engineering.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Dept. of Mechanical Engineering.

scopecontent.p: The Minutes series, 1922-2007 (5.0 linear feet), includes chronologically arranged minutes of both Faculty Meetings and Advisory Committees covering the periods 1922-1941 and 1984-2007. There is a considerable gap in this series between 1941 and 1984; this may be the result of individual chairs, rather than the department itself, overseeing records. Later minutes also frequently include meeting agendas, notes, handouts from meetings, and other information relating to decision-making at faculty and advisory committee meetings, such as faculty hiring and promotion and course approvals. The minutes of the Advisory Committee occasionally discuss personal matters and are subject to the 30-year personnel record restriction.

The E-Mail to Faculty series, 1993-1996 (.5 linear feet) includes printouts of e-mail messages and informational notices sent to the mechanical engineering faculty mailing list during this time period.

The Office Files series, ca. 1914-1993 (2.0 linear feet), is arranged in two subseries: General Files, and External Communications. The General Files subseries is an alphabetically arranged assortment of office files. Many of the files are background files for departmental annual reports and other departmental projects. A number of the files are from an earlier time period documenting the department's function of testing mufflers for various manufacturers during the early part of the 20th century. These files include black and white photographs of mufflers, drawings, graphs, and lab reports. The External Communications subseries is an arrangement of photographs, line drawings, graphs, and other background material used to illustrate faculty publications, press releases, and other departmental communications. The subseries is organized by the last name and first initial of the faculty member. The original arrangement of the subseries was maintained. The subseries includes one outsized folder of mechanical engineering drawings.

World Solar Challenge, (includes some e-mail correspondence) 1993

scopecontent.p: The Contact Sheets series, ca. 1985-2000 (2.0 linear feet), is a numerical sequence of contact prints that coordinate with the 4x6 prints found in the Photographs series and the Negatives series. The contact sheets are held in large three-ring binders.

The Photographs series, ca. 1985-2000 (10.0 linear feet), includes two subseries, 4x6 Prints and Topical. The 4x6 Prints subseries is a numerical sequence of 35 mm color photographs. The photographs date from the 1985-2000 time period. The 4x6 Prints correspond with materials in the Contact Sheets and Negatives series. The photographs in this series include views of award banquets, student projects, and faculty and staff. The Topical subseries is a series of photographs alphabetically arranged by topic. This subseries contains the most complete collection of faculty portraits. Most of the photographs in this subseries date from the 1990s, however, there are some earlier black and white photographs included. A number of these photographs seem to be reprints from the Michigan Historical Collections. The Topical subseries includes one outsized folder of large black and white photographs.

did.unittitle: Engineering Research Center for Reconfigurable Machining Systems (ERC/RMS) undated
High Tech Engine Test Car undated
Miscellaneous Research undated (plus one outsized folder filed in Box 18)

scopecontent.p: The series Panoramic Prints, and Slides, 1997-2000 (1.0 linear feet), includes a small number of panoramic photographs and a group of 35 mm slides. The color images are mostly winter and spring views of North Campus. The 35 mm slides are color slides and are stored in the original boxes they were received in. The slides are largely unidentified.

did.unittitle: North Campus and Maria Comninou's class March 2000

scopecontent.p: The Negatives series, 1985-2000 (1.0 linear feet), utilizes the same numerical sequence and organization found in the Contact Sheets series and the 4 x 6 Prints subseries.

The Website series, June 2001 (1.0 linear foot and 1,899 digital records, 140.3 MB), comprises a point-in-time snapshot record of the departmental website. The snapshot of the website was captured by the department. The information found within this series is as of June 2001. The website content and structure is stored as both a paper printout and as a digital version on CD-ROM. The paper printout version is arranged in two large three-ring binders. The first binder includes the website sections, Academic Programs and Admissions, Program Requirements, News and Information, People, Research, and Student Organizations. The second binder includes departmental publications Annual Reports (1994-2000) Mechanic (1998-2000), and Graduate Program Handbooks (1996-1999). The CD-ROM version is a digital copy of the site as of June 2001. The CD-ROM version maintains the original functionality contained in the structure of the site through the use of hypertext links.

did.unittitle: Volume One (paper printout and digital files stored on CD-ROM)
Volume Two (paper printout and digital files stored on CD-ROM)
